documents.title: Memorandum of Law in Support of Plaintiffs' Motion for Final Approval of Settlement and Class Certification
documents.text:
Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 160    Filed 02/25/11   Page 1 of 13
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF PENNSYLVANIA 
 
 
HARRY DELANDRO and KAREN  )   
MURPHY, individually and on behalf of a  )   
Class of others similarly situated,      )   
  )   
    Plaintiffs,  )   
  )  Civil Action No.:  2:06-CV-927 
  vs.  ) 
  ) 
THE COUNTY OF ALLEGHENY,  ) 
  ) 
    Defendant.  ) 
_____________________________________  )   
 
 
MEMORANDUM OF LAW IN SUPPORT OF  
PLAINTIFFS’ MOTION FOR FINAL APPROVAL OF  
SETTLEMENT AND CLASS CERTIFICATION 
 
The Plaintiffs, Karen Murphy and Harry Delandro (together, “Plaintiffs”), on behalf of 
themselves and all others similarly situated, through counsel of record ("Plaintiffs’ Class 
Counsel"), respectfully submit this Memorandum of Law in Support of Plaintiffs’ Motion for 
Final Approval of Settlement and Class Certification.  Pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil 
Procedure 23, Plaintiffs request this Court give Final Approval of the Class Settlement and 
certify the action pursuant to Rule 23. 
I.   PRELIMINARY STATEMENT 
  On September 10, 2010, Plaintiffs and Defendant executed a Settlement to resolve the 
above matter for a total of $3,000,000.00 million.  On September 15, 2010, Plaintiffs moved this 
Court for an Order preliminarily approving the Settlement and authorizing Plaintiffs and 
Defendant to provide Notice to the Class.  Pursuant to Plaintiffs’ motion, on September 30, 2010, 
this Court preliminarily approved the Settlement including the Notice.  Pursuant to this Court’s 
 1 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 160    Filed 02/25/11   Page 2 of 13
Order, the Settlement Administrator sent Notice out to the Class on November 29, 2010 by way 
of regular mail.  See Affidavit of Frank Barkan (“Barkan Aff.”) (Dkt. No. 158-2).  All mail that 
was undeliverable because of inaccurate addresses was investigated to ascertain the correct 
address and re-mailed to the members of the Class using a locater database.  Id. at ¶ 2.  Further, 
Plaintiffs and Defendant also provided Notice by way of newspaper publication and television.  
Finally, the Settlement Administrator created and implemented of telephone program using both 
interactive Voice Response technology and live operators.  Id.   
  The response to the Class Settlement by the Class has been overwhelmingly positive.  As 
of this filing, there have been over 2,085 (unverified) claim forms submitted pursuant to the 
Settlement, resulting in a claims rate of approximately 17%.  Barkan Aff. at ¶ 2.  Therefore, the 
Class has participated at a high rate.  Further, of this filing, only five members of the Class have 
opted out, and only one Class Member has objected.  See Affirmation of Lead Counsel Elmer 
Robert Keach, III in Support of Plaintiffs’ Motion for Final Approval of Class Action Settlement 
(“Keach Aff.”) at ¶ 10.  (Dkt. No. 158-1).     
II.  BRIEF FACTUAL BACKGROUND OF THE CASE 
The Plaintiffs brought an action against the Defendant asserting the Defendant 
maintained an unconstitutional strip search policy and practice throughout the Class Period.  
Plaintiffs allege that detainees admitted on misdemeanor or lesser offenses were strip-searched in 
the absence of individualized reasonable suspicion after being transported to the County of 
Allegheny County Jail (“Jail”).  Testimony of Allegheny County Jail personnel confirmed these 
allegations.  These strip-searches involved a visual inspection of detainees’ naked bodies and of 
their body cavities by a same-sex correctional officer in the privacy of a shower stall.  To 
facilitate an inspection of body cavities, detainees were required to manipulate their genitalia and 
 2 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 160    Filed 02/25/11   Page 3 of 13
buttocks, and “squat and cough” in view of a corrections officer.  Female detainees were also 
required to manipulate their breasts. The deposition testimony of the prison officers confirms this 
practice.  
In prosecution of these claims over four years, Class Counsel have reviewed hundreds of 
documents, have taken and defended numerous depositions, and have interviewed many fact 
witnesses.  Class Counsel also participated in several court proceedings, and filed and defended 
multiple substantive motions before the Court.  On March 24, 2010, after many months of 
negotiations and with the help of Magistrate Judge Robert C. Mitchell and retired Magistrate 
Judge Kenneth J. Benson, Plaintiffs and Defendant settled the matter.  During the course of these 
negotiations, the County agreed to change its strip-search policies, and stopped conducting 
blanket strip-searches on misdemeanor detainees.  The procedure developed by the County for its 
intake of detainees into the Jail facilities is a model policy, in that it balances the need of the 
County to keep contraband from entering the Jail at the same time it recognizes the rights of 
detainees for bodily privacy.  Although these lengthy and complex negotiations have been 
difficult, the Parties' good-faith efforts to resolve this Litigation ultimately resulted in an arms-
length Settlement representing a thoughtful compromise (which takes into consideration the 
Parties respective concerns – a meaningful solution to the constitutional violations incurred by 
the members of the Class and the County of Allegheny’s financial situation). In short, Plaintiffs 
respectfully submit that this Settlement is fair, reasonable and adequate for the Settlement Class, 
and that the requirements for final approval are satisfied.   
III.  THE SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT 
Plaintiffs are pleased to present to the Court Plaintiffs’ and Defendant’s Motion for Final 
Approval of the Settlement of this Litigation. This Settlement is made on behalf of all persons 
 3 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 160    Filed 02/25/11   Page 4 of 13
admitted to the Jail between July 13, 2004 and March 18, 2008 after being charged with 
misdemeanor offenses (or other minor crimes) and who were subsequently strip searched upon 
their entry into the Jail.  
All persons who have been incarcerated at the Allegheny County 
Jail commencing on July 13, 2004 and continuing to March 18, 
2008 who, after being charged but not convicted of misdemeanors, 
summary offenses, civil commitments and traffic infractions as 
defined by the laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, as well 
as parole or probation violations where the underlying offense is a 
misdemeanor, summary offense or traffic infraction, pursuant to 
the policy of Allegheny County, have been strip searched upon 
their  entry  into  the  Allegheny  County  Jail  without  reasonable 
suspicion. 
 
As described below, the Settlement Agreement provides for the creation of a Settlement 
Fund to compensate the Settlement Class for these constitutional violations. 
A.  The Settlement Fund  
  The Settlement creates a Settlement Fund of $3,000,000.00.  Class members will receive 
their pro rata share of the Settlement Fund after the payment of attorneys’ fees, expenses, 
incentive awards, and administrative and Notice expenses.  Given the claims rate to date, and 
assuming an ultimate claims rate of 20%, Class Counsel estimates that each Class Member will 
receive a pro rata payment of $662.77.  See Keach Aff. at ¶ 13.   
Class Counsel will also seek thirty-three and a third percent (33 1/3%) of the Settlement 
Fund for attorneys’ fees pursuant to the Settlement Agreement.  Class Counsel is filing a petition 
for attorneys’ fees simultaneously with this motion for final approval of the settlement. 
IV.  LEGAL ARGUMENT 
The Third Circuit requires that before a Class Settlement Agreement is approved, the 
Court must find that the Settlement is fair, reasonable and adequate.  See Girsh v. Jepson, 521 
F.2d 153 (3d Cir. 1975).  The Court must then find the class meets the requirements set forth 
 4 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 160    Filed 02/25/11   Page 5 of 13
under Rule 23 and if it does, certify the class.  As will be demonstrated below, Plaintiffs’ and 
Defendant’s Settlement Agreement meets this burden.  Final approval should be granted and the 
Settlement Class should be certified. 
     A.   The Settlement Agreement Should Be Approved By the Court 
 
In this motion, Plaintiffs seek Final Approval of the Settlement Agreement between 
Plaintiffs and the Defendant. "Compromises of disputed claims are favored by the courts."  
Williams v. First Nat'l Bank, 216 U.S. 582, 595 (1910); In re Prudential Ins. Co. Am. Sales 
Practice Litig. Agent Actions, 148 F.3d 283, 317 (3d Cir. 1998) ("Prudential II”).  The 
Settlement spares the litigants the uncertainty, delay and expense of a trial, while simultaneously 
reducing the burden on judicial resources.  Federal Rule 23(e) provides that the Court must 
approve any Settlement of a Class action. In a Class action, the "court plays the important role of 
protector of the [absent members'] interests, in a sort of fiduciary capacity." In re Gen. Motors 
Corp. Pick-up Truck Fuel Tank Prods. Liab. Litig., 55 F.3d 768, 785 (3rd Cir. 1995) ("GM 
Trucks").  The ultimate determination whether a proposed Class action Settlement warrants 
approval resides in the Court's discretion.  See Protective Comm. for Indep. S'holders of TMT 
Trailer Ferry, Inc. v. Anderson, 390 U.S. 414, 424-25 (1968).  A Class Settlement should be 
approved when the court finds it is fair, reasonable and adequate.  See Fry v. Hayt, Hayt & 
Landau, 198 F.R.D. 461, 470 (E.D. Pa. 2000). 
The Third Circuit has adopted a nine-factor test to determine whether a Class Settlement 
is fair, reasonable and adequate:  
“…(1) the complexity, expense and likely duration of the litigation…; (2) 
the reaction of the Class to the Settlement…; (3) the stage of the 
proceedings and the amount of discovery completed…; (4) the risks of 
establishing liability…’ (5) the risks of establishing damages…(6) the 
risks of maintaining the Class action through trial…; (7) the ability of the 
Defendants to withstand a greater judgment; (8) the range of 
 5 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 160    Filed 02/25/11   Page 6 of 13
reasonableness of the Settlement fund in light of the best possible 
recovery…; (9) the range of reasonableness of the Settlement fund to a 
possible recovery in light of all the attendant risks of litigation…” 
 
Girsh, 521 F.2d at 157. 
Plaintiffs’ and Defendant’s Settlement meets this burden. 
1.  The Complexity, Expenses and Likely Duration of the 
Litigation Support Final Approval 
 
As stated above, Plaintiffs began this action on July 13, 2006.  Class Counsel have 
conducted numerous depositions and also have filed a motion for summary judgment, motion for 
class certification and motion for preliminary injunction.  Class Counsel have interviewed over 
numerous Class Members in investigating the Class in support of Plaintiffs’ motion for class 
certification.  In all, Plaintiffs’ counsel has incurred a cumulative lodestar $1,258,165.00 on this 
case.  Keach Aff. at ¶ 11 attached.  Further, Class Counsel has out-of-pocket costs in excess of $ 
148,722.17, although a significant portion of these expenses is the result of Class Counsel paying 
for the initial administrative expenses of the settlement.  Id. at ¶ 12. 
Plaintiffs sought a sound and efficient resolution of the claims through settlement, in part, 
because of their awareness that the Third Circuit had granted review of a similar case on the 
issue of liability and that the Class could soon have no viable claims.  Plaintiffs’ reasoning 
proved sound.   After the parties reached a settlement, the Third Circuit held that a blanket policy 
of strip-searching all non-indictable arrestees admitted to a jail facility without first articulating 
reasonable suspicion does not violate the Fourth Amendment.  Florence v. Bd. Of Chosen 
Freeholders of Co. of Burlington, 621 F.3d 296, 310 (3d Cir. 2010).  Thus, in the absence of a 
settlement, class members, who present nearly identical allegations as those in Florence, would 
 6 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 160    Filed 02/25/11   Page 7 of 13
very likely not have viable claims and would therefore receive no compensation.1  In light of 
Florence and based on the experience of Class Counsel, the Settlement of $3,000,000.00 million 
provided certainty to Class Members and provided a fair and reasonable result for the outcome.  
See In Re Automotive Refinishing Paint Antitrust Litigation, 617 F. Supp. 2d 336, 341 (E.D. Pa. 
2007) (judgment of experienced counsel supported providing final approval for Settlement).   
This is especially so given the County’s financial situation, and its lack of insurance coverage.  
In sum, Class Counsel in this case weighed the risks of proceeding further with litigation with 
the benefit of receiving a Settlement and concluded it was in the Class members’ best interest to 
resolve this matter at this juncture.  Therefore, the Settlement is fair, reasonable and adequate.   
2.  The Reaction of the Class Justifies Final Approval 
Under the second Girsh factor, the reaction of the Class is evidence as whether the 
Settlement is fair, reasonable and adequate.  See Prudential II, 148 F.3d at 318; In Re Automotive 
Refinishing Paint Antitrust Litigation, 617 F. Supp. 2d at 342.   
Pursuant to this Court’s Order of preliminary approval and the agreed upon notice 
program, Plaintiffs provided to the Class through the Settlement Administrator.  See Barkan Aff.   
The Settlement Administrator arranged for the printing and mailing of a Notice and Proof of 
Claim Form to the approximately 12,398 Class Members.  Id. at ¶ 2.  The Settlement 
Administrator coordinated the publication of the Summary Notice in various newspapers, and 
coordinated the implementation of television commercials pursuant to the agreed upon Notice 
program.  Id.  The Settlement Administrator also contracted with a website administrator to 
                                                 
1 It bears mentioning that class counsel in Florence have filed a petition for writ of certiorari 
with the U.S. Supreme Court.  Any given petition, however, has less than a one percent chance 
of being granted.  See Journal of the Supreme Court of the United States, October Term 2005, at 
II (2006), http://www.supremecourtus.gov/orders/journal/jnl05.pdf (documenting that of the 
8,521 cases docketed during the October 2005 term, only 78 cases were granted plenary review). 
 7 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 160    Filed 02/25/11   Page 8 of 13
develop a dedicated website for the Settlement.  Id.   
Finally, Plaintiffs have received 2,085 claim forms from unverified class members with a 
desire to participate in this Settlement.  Id.  This represents overwhelming support for the Class.  
The fact that only one Class member filed an objection is a significant element to consider when 
assessing the fairness of the Settlement.  See In Re Cendant Corp. Litig., 264 F.3d 201, 264 (3d 
Cir. 2001).  
Only five Class members have decided to opt out of the settlement.  Keach Aff. at ¶ Id.  
Only one has objected to the Settlement.  Id.  This objection, lodged by class member April 
Taylor, is without merit since it alleges that the settlement does not offer her sufficient 
compensation for her injuries.  Keach Aff. at ¶ 10.  Absent the class settlement, class members 
would most likely receive nothing since the given the Third Circuit’s decision in Florence.   
      3.  The Stage of the Proceeding and Amount of Discovery Favor 
Final Approval 
 
It has been generally understood by the Third Circuit that settlements that are made after 
discovery reflect the true value of the claim.  See Bell Atlantic Corp. v. Bolger, 2 F.3d 1304, 
1314 (3d Cir. 1993).  Plaintiffs and Defendant in this case completed discovery.  Class Counsel 
took numerous depositions and reviewed hundreds of documents regarding the admittance of 
pretrial detainees at the Jail.  Since Plaintiffs prosecuted this action and completed discovery 
before resolving the claims of the Class, this weighs heavily in favor of approving the Settlement 
as fair, reasonable and adequate.  Id. 
4.  The Risks of Establishing Liability and Damages Weigh in 
Favor of Approving Settlement. 
 
The risks of establishing liability and damages are the fourth and fifth factors to be 
weighed when evaluating a Settlement.  See In Re Automotive Refinishing Paint Antitrust 
 8 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 160    Filed 02/25/11   Page 9 of 13
Litigation, 617 F. Supp. 2d at 343.  This factor in and of itself counsels for approval of this 
Settlement.  After the parties reached a settlement, the Third Circuit held that a blanket policy of 
strip-searching all non-indictable arrestees admitted to a jail facility without first articulating 
reasonable suspicion does not violate the Fourth Amendment.  Florence, 621 F.3d at 310.  In 
other words, in the absence of a settlement, Class Members would likely not have viable claims 
and would receive no compensation.  
In this case, the Settlement provides class members with a $3,000,000.00 fund.  Their 
Settlement clearly meets the standard of fairness, reasonableness and adequacy as found by 
courts in similar Settlements.  Class Counsel estimates that Class members will receive 
approximately $662.77.  Keach Off. at ¶ 13. 
5.  The Risks of Maintaining a Class Action Through Trial Weigh 
in Favor of Approving this Settlement 
 
Given the Florence decision, the risks of maintaining a Class through trial support 
approval of the Settlement.  See Prudential II, 148 F.3d at 321.  In light of the fact that the Third 
Circuit has found that a district court always possesses the authority to decertify an action, this 
factor in and of itself weighs in favor of Settlement.  “Consistent with this reality, we are 
satisfied that the inherent difficulties of bringing a Class action to trial weighs in favor of 
approving the Settlements.”  In Re Automotive Refinishing Paint Antitrust Litigation, 617 
F.Supp. 2d at 344.  This Court should find that this factor weighs strongly in favor of approving 
the Settlement. 
6.  The Ability of Defendants to Withstand Greater Judgment 
 
  Under the seventh Girsh factor, it must be considered whether the Defendant could 
withstand a greater judgment.  See In Re Diet Drugs Products Liability Litigation, 2000 WL 
1222042 at *62 (E.D. Pa. August 28, 2000).  In this case, the Defendant, the County of 
 9 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 160    Filed 02/25/11   Page 10 of 13
Allegheny, has suffered, as have most municipalities, from the current economic conditions. Due 
to the realities of the environment, this factor weighs heavily in finding that the Settlement for 
$3,000,000.00 million is fair, reasonable and adequate. 
7.   The Reasonableness of the Settlement in Light of the Best 
Possible Recovery Weighs in Favor of Approving this 
Settlement 
 
The final two Girsh factors require the court to determine whether Plaintiffs settled for 
appropriate value in light of the Class members’ damages.  See In Re Automotive Refinishing 
Paint Antitrust Litigation, 617 F. Supp. 2d at 344.  This matter settled for $3,000,000.00 million.  
Each Class member will receive approximately$662.77.  Under Third Circuit precedent 
delivered after the settlement was reached, Plaintiffs would be most likely be unable to state 
viable claims and would receive no compensation.  In addition, in settlements of similar actions, 
Class members have received comparable amounts.  As is demonstrated by the above analysis of 
the Girsh factors, the Settlement is clearly an excellent result and is fair, reasonable and adequate 
under Girsh. 
B.  Final Certification of the Proposed Settlement Class is Appropriate to                                      
Resolve All Strip-search Claims Against Defendant 
  
Although the Settlement is fair, reasonable and adequate, the Settlement Class still must 
be certified pursuant to Rule 23.  Both the Supreme Court and various circuit courts have 
recognized that the benefits of a proposed Settlement of a Class action can only be realized 
through the certification of a Settlement Class.  See Amchem Prods. v. Windsor, 521 U.S. 591 
(1997); Prudential II, 148 F.3d 283; Hanlon v. Chrysler Corp., 150 F.3d 1011 (9th Cir. 1998).   
Given that this case has already been certified the Court for trial purposes, there can be 
little question that the Settlement Class readily meets the necessary criteria of numerosity, 
commonality, typicality, and adequacy.  See Dkt. No. 99.  Since the Settlement Class consists of 
 10 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 160    Filed 02/25/11   Page 11 of 13
approximately 12,398 individuals, there is no question that the element of numerosity has been 
met. The commonality and typicality requirements are also easily satisfied, as the claims of the 
Class Representatives and the Settlement Class are premised upon the same blanket strip-search 
and bail policy and practice. Finally, adequacy of representation is assured as the Settlement 
Class is represented by counsel who have a wealth of experience in complex civil rights 
litigation.  
Certification of a Class under Rule 23(b)(3) for Settlement of the compensatory damages 
claims is also appropriate because such relief is premised on the common constitutional 
violations visited on the Settlement Class by the Defendant’s allegedly unlawful strip-search 
policy.  There is no danger that individual variations in the type or magnitude of damage suffered 
by individual Class members will affect predominance, as the Representative Plaintiffs have 
suffered the same type of damages -- and seek the same type of relief -- as members of the 
proposed Settlement Class.  Moreover, resolution of this Litigation by a Class Settlement is 
superior to the individual adjudication of Class members' claims for compensatory relief.  In 
particular, the Settlement provides the Settlement Class with an ability to obtain prompt, 
predictable and certain compensatory relief, and contains well defined administrative procedures 
to assure due process in the application of the agreement to each individual claimant including 
the right to "opt-out." By contrast, individualized litigation here carries with it near certainty of 
that individuals would receive no compensation given the Third Circuit’s recently holding in 
Florence.   
Other federal courts, in considering the situation where cities or counties have employed 
blanket search policies, have consistently recognized the propriety of certifying such cases as 
 11 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 160    Filed 02/25/11   Page 12 of 13
Class actions and the decisions certifying such cases are legion.2  In sum, given that the Court 
has already certified this Class for trial, the requirements of Rule 23(b)(3) are satisfied and 
certification of the proposed Settlement Class is appropriate.  
V.     CONCLUSION 
For the foregoing reasons, Plaintiffs and Defendant respectfully request that this Court 
enter an Order that: (1) provides final approval to the Settlement as fair, reasonable and 
adequate, and (2) certifies the Class for settlement purposes pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3) 
for the purpose of effectuating a Class action Settlement of the claims against the Defendant.   
          Respectfully Submitted By 
             /s Elmer Robert Keach, III 
Dated:  February 25, 2011      ___________________________________ 
  Elmer Robert Keach, III, Esquire (Lead Counsel) 
  Member of the Bar, United States District Court 
  for the Western District of Pennsylvania 
LAW OFFICES OF ELMER ROBERT  
KEACH, III, PC 
1040 Riverfront Center 
Post Office Box 70 
Amsterdam, NY  12010 
518.434.1718 
 
D. AARON RIHN, ESQUIRE 
Pa. I.D. No.: 85752 
ROBERT PEIRCE & ASSOCIATES, P.C. 
2500 Gulf Tower 
                                                 
2 See e.g., Mitchell v. County of Clinton, 2007 WL 19887126 (N.D.N.Y. July 5, 2007); Marriott 
v. County of Montgomery, 227 F.R.D. 159 (N.D.N.Y. 2005), aff'd, 2005 WL 3117194 (2d Cir. 
2005) (litigated by present Class counsel); Marriott v. County of Montgomery, 426 F. Supp. 2d 1 
(N.D.N.Y. 2006); Kahler v. County of Rensselaer, No. 03-CV-1324 (N.D.N.Y. 2004) (litigated 
by present Class counsel); Dodge v. County of Orange, 226 F.R.D. 117 (S.D.N.Y. 2005); Calvin 
v. Sheriff of Will County, 2004 WL 1125922 (N.D. Ill. May 17, 2004); Blihovde v. St. Croix 
County, Wis., 219 F.R.D. 607 (W.D. Wis. 2003); Tardiff, 218 F.R.D. 332; Nilsen, 219 F.R.D. 19; 
Bynum v. Dist. of Columbia, 217 F.R.D. 43 (D.D.C. 2003); Ford v. City of Boston, 154 F. Supp. 
2d 123 (D. Mass. 2001); Mack v. Suffolk Co., 91 F.R.D. 16 (D. Mass. 2000); Gary v. Sheahan, 
1999 WL 281347 (N.D. Ill. Mar. 31, 1999); Tyson v. City of New York, No. 97 Civ. 3762 
(S.D.N.Y. Mar. 18, 1998); Eddleman v. Jefferson Co., Ky., 99 F.3d 1448 (6th Cir. 1996).   
 12

documents.title: Plaintiffs' Consolidated Brief in Response to Defendant's Motion for Summary Judgment and in Further Support of Plaintiffs Motion for Partial Summary Judgment on Liability
documents.text:
Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 116    Filed 06/26/09   Page 1 of 13
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT  
FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF PENNSYLVANIA  
____________________________________    
                                                              :          
HARRY DELANDRO and KAREN    : 
MURPHY, individually and on behalf of   : 
a class of  all others similarly situated,  :     
      :             
    Plaintiffs,      :  Civil Action No. 2:06-CV-927 
            :           
- vs -          :     
          :    
ALLEGHENY COUNTY, et al.,     :   
            :     
Defendants.      :      
____________________________________: 
 
 
PLAINTIFFS’ CONSOLIDATED BRIEF IN RESPONSE TO DEFENDANTS’ MOTION 
FOR SUMMARY JUDGMENT AND IN FURTHER SUPPORT OF PLAINTIFFS 
MOTION FOR PARTIAL SUMMARY JUDGMENT ON LIABILITY 
 
 
I.  INTRODUCTION AND SUMMARY OF ARGUMENT 
 
  Plaintiffs submit this consolidated brief in response to Defendants’ motion for summary 
judgment and in further support of Plaintiffs’ motion for partial summary judgment on liability.  
Defendants’ response to Plaintiffs’ motion for partial summary judgment and Defendants’ 
motion for summary judgment largely rehash the same meritless arguments that Defendants 
made – and the Court rejected -- in opposition to class certification.  Specifically, Defendants 
argue: 1) that Plaintiffs have failed to demonstrate a custom or policy of blanket strip searches 
for all pre-trial detainees who are admitted into the Allegheny County Jail (“ACJ”); 2) that 
Allegheny County does not have an illegal blanket strip search policy because it employs a 
multi-stage procedure of admitting detainees; 3) that the caselaw supposedly permits blanket 
strip searches of pre-trial detainees without reasonable suspicion; 4) that the representative 
Plaintiffs are not entitled to summary judgment because a) Mr. Delandro was on crutches and 
1 
 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 116    Filed 06/26/09   Page 2 of 13
wore a foot immobilizer, and b) there is purportedly no record of Ms. Murphy’s admission to the 
Allegheny.   
Defendants further contend that the individual defendants should be dismissed because of 
the doctrine of qualified immunity.  While Plaintiffs do not agree with Defendants’ argument 
concerning qualified immunity, they will nevertheless agree to dismiss the individual defendants 
given the County’s direct liability for their admitted blanket strip search policy and practice.  
Defendants remaining arguments lack merit, and for the following reasons detailed further 
below, must fail.   
  The Plaintiffs have amply demonstrated the existence of blanket strip search policy at the 
ACJ through FRCP 30(b)(6) deposition testimony; a written policy promulgated by Allegheny 
County, and through the depositions of various Corrections Officers who work at the ACJ.  They 
have also demonstrated this blanket policy in sworn testimony before the Court during a 
preliminary injunction hearing.  The so-called multi-stage admissions process does not immunize 
Allegheny County from liability because all class members are stripped searched without 
reasonable suspicion after being charged only with minor offenses regardless of the multi-stage 
admissions process. 
  Additionally, the limited decisions cited by Defendants in support of their request for 
summary judgment are unavailing because they represent factually distinguishable situations or 
are otherwise wrongly decided—nearly all of them are also from outside this judicial circuit.  
The near-unanimous authority holds that blanket strip searches of pretrial detainees are 
unconstitutional, and yesterday’s Supreme Court decision in Safford Unified Sch. Dist. #1 v. 
Redding, ___ S.Ct. ___, 2009 WL 1789472 (2009) reaffirmed the requirement that strip searches 
must be supported by reasonable suspicion.   
2 
 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 116    Filed 06/26/09   Page 3 of 13
  In short, the representative Plaintiffs are entitled to summary judgment on liability 
because they were both strip searched pursuant to Allegheny County’s blanket policy without 
reasonable suspicion.        
II.  ARGUMENT 
  A.  The Court Should Grant Plaintiffs’ Motion For Partial Summary Judgment  
    And Deny Defendants’ Motion for Summary Judgment With Respect To  
    Allegheny County. 
 
  1.  Plaintiffs Have Amply Demonstrated A Policy/Practice Of Blanket 
  Strip Searches For All Pre-Trial Detainees Who Were Admitted to the 
  General Population of the ACJ. 
 
  Defendants argue that the Plaintiffs have not demonstrated that Allegheny County had a 
policy or custom of blanket strip searches at the ACJ.  This argument strains credulity.  Plaintiffs 
have amply demonstrated that Allegheny County had a blanket strip search policy for pre-trial 
detainees who are admitted to the general population.  As detailed in Plaintiffs’ opening brief, 
the County, in response to a deposition notice pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. Proc. Rule 30(b)(6), 
proffered Corrections Lieutenant Phil Cestra as its designated deponent. (See Plaintiffs’ Notice 
of Deposition, dated May 8, 2007) (Attached as Ex. C to Keach Aff., Doc. No. 107).  Lieutenant 
Cestra is the officer primarily in charge of the “Intake/Booking Area” of the Allegheny County 
Jail. (Allegheny County Dep., p. 14) (Attached as Ex. D to Keach Aff., Doc. No. 107). 
Lieutenant Cestra admitted that all detainees are subjected to a blanket strip search when 
receiving the jail uniform in “Phase 6” of the booking process at the Allegheny County Jail, 
according to the express requirements of Allegheny County’s written policies. (Allegheny 
County Dep., pp. 20-22, 111, 155-56, 165-67; Allegheny County Administrative Directive 
Number 16, “Methods of Searching Inmates,” p. 3 (Keach Aff., Ex. E, Doc. No. 107)).   
  Five other ACJ Corrections Officers confirmed that blanket strip searches of all pre-trial 
3 
 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 116    Filed 06/26/09   Page 4 of 13
detainees admitted to the ACJ had been the custom and practice of the County through 
Deposition testimony or testimony at the Preliminary Injunction Hearing held before the Court 
on March 17, 2008.  See Plaintiffs’ opening brief at 4-5 (Doc. No. 108).   
  It is well established that “the testimony of the Rule 30(b)(6) designee is deemed to be 
the testimony of the corporation itself.”  State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. New Horizont, Inc., 
250 F.R.D. 203, 212 (E.D. Pa. 2008).  Where a defendant fails to controvert 30(b)(6) testimony 
with other evidence and a reasonable explanation as to why it was not offered earlier, the 
30(b)(6) testimony controls.  See id.  Here, Defendants have proffered no evidence whatsoever to 
contradict the evidence of a blanket strip search policy at the ACJ taken from their 30(b)(6) 
deponent Lieutenant Cestra, the County’s written strip search policies, and the testimony of 
various other Corrections Officers at the ACJ.1  Accordingly, there can be no genuine issue of 
material fact concerning the existence of blanket strip search policy at the ACJ, or Allegheny 
County’s liability for that policy.  See, e.g., Bartholomew v. Fischl, 782 F.2d 1148, 1153 (3d Cir. 
1986).             
 
 
  
                                                 
1 For this reason, the cases relied upon by Defendants are inapposite.  See Carswell v. Borough of Homestead, 381 
F.3d 235, 245 (3d Cir. 2004) (finding that the plaintiff failed to establish a lack of training on the use of deadly force 
that amounted to a deliberate indifference, or demonstrate a pattern of underlying constitutional violations that 
should have alerted the municipality to an inadequate training program); Gagliardi v. County of Allegheny  2007 
WL 838971, * 4 (W.D. Pa., 2007) (granting summary judgment for defendants because “No reasonable jury could 
conclude on this record that the Allegheny County Correctional Medical Technician Defendants . . .were 
deliberately indifferent to Plaintiff's serious medical needs”); Smith v. Municipality of Lycoming County  2006 WL 
1793228, * 3 (M.D. Pa., 2006) (“Smith fails to allege any direct involvement on the part of Lycoming County. Nor 
does he allege that Lycoming County undertook any act pursuant to an official municipal policy or custom of some 
nature which caused the alleged Constitutional violation.”); Ludaway v. City of Jacksonville, Fla., 2007 WL 
2455348, * 3 (11th Cir. 2007) (“because a reasonable juror could not find that the use of excessive force among 
officers in the JSO was so widespread as to have acquired the force of law” plaintiff  failed to show the “alleged use 
of excessive force was the result of the City's policy or custom”).  Here, there is no dispute that the strip searches in 
question are conducted pursuant to the County’s written policies.   
4 
 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 116    Filed 06/26/09   Page 5 of 13
    2.  The Fact That Detainees May Only Be Strip Searched Prior To Their  
      Entrance Into The General Population Of The ACJ Does Not    
      Undermine Plaintiffs’ Claim Of A Fourth Amendment Violation. 
 
  Defendants contend that because the class members are not strip searched at their “entry 
into the jail” but rather only at their admission into the “general population” after a multi-stage 
intake process, no Constitutional violations have occurred.  Defendants’ argument misses the 
mark.  Indeed, the multi-stage intake process is a distinction without any difference.  Despite the 
multi-stage intake process, the ACJ has a blanket strip search policy - all detainees with the 
minor offenses detailed in the class definition who receive the jail uniform and enter the general 
population are strip searched without reasonable suspicion and are perforce class members.  
Detainees who are bailed out and do not receive prison clothing or enter the general population 
may not be strip searched and would therefore not be class members.  The crux of the matter is 
that all class members are strip searched without reasonable suspicion after being charged only 
with minor offenses; it does not matter exactly at what point in the intake process that the 
detainee is strip searched.  See, Shain v. Ellison, 273 F.3d 56,  (2d Cir. 2001) (post arraignment 
strip searches).   Defendants raised this same argument in opposition to Plaintiffs motions for 
class certification in a misguided attempt to show that the class was not properly defined, and the 
Court rejected it.  The Court should reject it again here.      
    3.  The Decisions Cited By Defendants Are Unavailing.   
  Defendants contend that the caselaw permits blanket strip searches of pre-trial detainees 
without reasonable suspicion.  To the contrary, as Plaintiffs detail in their opening brief, the near-
unanimous Federal case authority, some of which was recently decided by District Courts within 
the Third Circuit, holds that blanket jail strip searches of misdemeanor detainees are 
unconstitutional.  See, for example, Allison v. GEO Group, 611 F. Supp.2d 433 (E.D.Pa. 2009); 
5 
 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 116    Filed 06/26/09   Page 6 of 13
Newkirk v. Sheers, 834 F. Supp. 772 (E.D.Pa. 1993).  Further, only yesterday the U.S. Supreme 
Court again reaffirmed that strip searches may not be performed without reasonable suspicion.  
See Safford Unified Sch. Dist. #1 v. Redding,  ___ S.Ct. ___, 2009 WL 1789472 (2009) (Exhibit 
A, hereto).  In Safford the Supreme Court held a school’s strip search of student was a violation 
of the Fourth Amendment because it lacked reasonable suspicion where the school official knew 
the student only may have possessed over-the-counter pain relievers.  Id.  The Supreme Court 
found that: 
In sum, what was missing from the suspected facts that pointed to [plaintiff] was 
any indication of danger to the students from the power of the drugs or their 
quantity, and any reason to suppose that [plaintiff] was carrying pills in her 
underwear. We think that the combination of these deficiencies was fatal to 
finding the search reasonable. 
 
Id. at * 23.   
  The Supreme Court further found that to limit a search “to reasonable scope requires the 
support of reasonable suspicion of danger or of resort to underwear for hiding evidence of 
wrongdoing before a search can reasonably make the quantum leap from outer clothes and 
backpacks to exposure of intimate parts.”  Id. at * 24.  Thus, Safford underscores the bedrock 
requirement for reasonable suspicion to justify such an intrusive search as a strip search.                  
  Defendants first cite Powell v. Barrett, 541 F.3d 1298 (11th Cir. 2008) (en banc), which 
recently broke with the other Circuits’ interpretation of Bell.  Defendants’ reliance on Powell is 
misplaced because Plaintiffs maintain it was wrongly decided and is not persuasive authority.  
As an initial matter, Powell does not involve the intrusive visual cavity searches at issue in this 
litigation.  Powell, 541 F.3d at 1313 & n. 6 (“The strip searches of the five plaintiffs before us 
did not include body cavity inspections”).  Furthermore, conspicuously absent from Defendants’ 
briefs is the fact the two District Courts within this Circuit that have thoroughly examined 
6 
 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 116    Filed 06/26/09   Page 7 of 13
Powell and have found that it is wrongly decided.  See, Florence v. Bd. of Chosen Freeholders of 
Burlington, 595 F. Supp. 2d 492, 511 (D.N.J. 2009) (granting summary judgment for plaintiffs 
and finding that “this Court ultimately finds [Powell’s] contrarian holding less than compelling.  
The post-contact visit searches upheld in Bell are dissimilar to the post-intake searches struck 
down by the circuits in the thirty years since that decision. Thus, Powell does not present a 
convincing argument . . .”); see also, Allison v. GEO Group, 611 F. Supp.2d 433, 457 (E.D. Pa. 
2009) (denying defendant’s motion for judgment on the pleadings and noting that “this Court 
disagrees with both the reasoning and holding of the Eleventh Circuit in Powell”).  Accordingly, 
the Court should follow Florence and Allison and find that Powell does not provide support for 
Defendants’ position.   
  Defendants next cite to Dobrowolskyj v. Jefferson County, 823 F.2d 955 (6th Cir. 1987), 
to argue that there is no Constitutional violation for strip searching detainees prior to their being 
moved into the general population of the Allegheny County Jail.  Again, Defendants’ briefs 
contain a rather conspicuous omission – that the Sixth Circuit later clearly limited the holding of 
Dobrowolskyj by finding that “the fact of intermingling alone has never been found to justify 
such a search without consideration of the nature of the offense and the question of whether there 
is any reasonable basis for concern that the particular detainee will attempt to introduce weapons 
or other contraband to the institution.” Masters v. Crouch, 872 F.2d 1248, 1254 (6th Cir. 1989).  
  Defendants’ reliance upon Richerson v. Lexington Fayette Urban County Gov't, 958 F. 
Supp. 299, 307 (E.D. Ky. 1996) is similarly misplaced.  In Richerson, the pretrial detainees were 
brought to the courthouse for arraignment where they were exposed to the general public prior to 
being returned to the general prison population.  Id.  The Richerson court found that the exposure 
to the general public presented a danger of contraband being passed to a detainee, and therefore a 
7 
 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 116    Filed 06/26/09   Page 8 of 13
policy of strip searching the detainees upon their return from the courthouse and prior to their 
being placed back in the general population of the detention center was justified and reasonable.  
Id.  Here, the intake process at the ACJ presents no such opportunity for exposure to the public 
because the detainees do not leave the secure facility to travel to a courthouse for arraignment, 
nor do they have exposure to the public in the process.  See Hearing Transcript, Mar. 17, 2008, at 
22-27. (Doc. 107-11).  Rather, arraignment occurs in the same secure facility because a detainee 
only walks through a hallway to be arraigned.  Id.  Thus, Dobrowolskyj and Richerson provide 
no support for Defendants.         
  Stanley v. Henson, 337 F.3d 961, 964 (7th Cir. 2003) is also distinguishable from the case 
at bar.  In Stanley, the defendant employed a clothing exchange procedure where the detainees 
only needed to undress to their undergarments.  Id.  Here, the strip searches conducted at the ACJ 
not only required detainees to strip naked, but also included visual examination of genitals, as 
well as requesting detainees to bend at the waist and/or manipulate the buttocks, breasts and 
genitals to allow for a visual inspection of their body cavities (including their anus) and skin 
folds.  See Plaintiffs’ opening brief at 3.  Thus, the clothing exchanges at issue in Stanley 
qualitatively differed from the far more intrusive strip searches at issue here.   
  Finally Inmates of Allegheny County Jail v. Pierce, 612 F.2d 754 (3d Cir. Pa. 1979), and 
Overton v. Bazzetta, 539 U.S. 126 cited by Defendants, are factually distinguishable from this 
case because neither involve blanket strip searches of pretrial detainees.  Rather, Inmates of 
Allegheny County Jail involved the propriety of strip searches for inmates after contact visits – a 
procedure that is not at issue in this case, 612 F.2d at 758, and Overton only dealt with 
restrictions on noncontact visits for inmates, and did not even mention strip searches.  539 U.S.  
at 131. 
8 
 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 116    Filed 06/26/09   Page 9 of 13
  In sum, the cases cited by Defendants are unavailing, especially when compared to the 
near-unanimous authority to the contrary, and the recent Supreme Court decision in Safford that 
reaffirmed the requirement of reasonable suspicion for the performance of strip searches.   
 
    4.  The Representative Plaintiffs Are Entitled To  
      Summary Judgment On Liability. 
 
  Defendants assert that Harry Delandro and Karen Murphy are not entitled to summary 
judgment on liability.  The first basis for this argument is that Defendants had reasonable 
suspicion to search Harry Delandro because he was on crutches and wearing a leg immobilizer, 
absurdly characterized by defendants as “steel bars,” at the time of his arrest due to recent 
surgery.  See Hearing Transcript, Mar. 17, 2008, pp. 15-19. (Doc. 107-11).  Indeed, just to state 
the argument that a plainly incapacitated man posed a security risk because of the walking aids 
he wore is to show its ridiculousness.  Further, Defendants’ own admissions are they never did a 
background check or considered, at the time they strip searched him, whether they had 
reasonable suspicion.  Because a defendant may not invent a post hoc justification for an 
unconstitutional strip search, Defendants’ argument fails.  See, Bizzarro v. Ocean County, 2009 
WL 1617887, * 13 (D.N.J. June 9, 2009) (“Defendants cannot create post-hoc rationales to 
manufacture justifications for conducting strip searches”); Doe v. Calumet City, 754 F. Supp. 
1211, 1220 (N.D. Ill. 1990) (defendant cannot avoid liability by manufacturing post-hoc basis for 
strip searches which were conducted pursuant to indiscriminate and routine policy).                   
  Defendants next argue that Karen Murphy was never in the Allegheny County Jail.  In 
light of the prior proof put before the Court, this argument is patently (and knowingly) false, and 
ridiculous.  Karen Murphy testified in open Court that she was in the ACJ and strip searched in 
August 2005.  See id., p. 20.  In addition to Ms. Murphy’s testimony, the ACJ Booking Sheets 
9 
 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 116    Filed 06/26/09   Page 10 of 13
further evidence that she was admitted to the ACJ during in August 2005.  See Allegheny County 
Jail Charge Sheet, attached hereto as Exh. B (indicating that Ms. Murphy’s was admitted into the 
ACJ in August 2005).  Thus, there can be no genuine issue of material fact concerning Ms. 
Murphy’s presence and strip search at the ACJ.        
  Defendants made these very same arguments in opposition to class certification and the 
Court rejected them.  The Court should reject them again here.        
 
  B.  Plaintiffs Seek Permission From The Court To Dismiss The  
    Individual Defendants.    
 
On August 8, 2008, this Court certified the above action against the County of Allegheny, 
Ramon C. Rustin in his individual capacity as warden of Allegheny County Jail, Edward Urban 
individually and in his official capacity as deputy warden of Allegheny County Jail, Gregory 
Grogan individually and in his official capacity as deputy warden of Allegheny County Jail, 
Lance Bohn individually and in his official capacity as deputy warden of Allegheny County Jail 
and William Emerick individually and in his official capacity as assistant deputy warden of 
Allegheny County Jail based on their unlawful strip searches of plaintiffs and members of the 
class.  (Doc. No. 99).  On May 26, 2009, Defendants moved for partial summary judgment of the 
above individual Defendants on the grounds of qualified immunity.  Plaintiffs seek permission 
from this Court to dismiss the individual Defendants Ramon Rustin, Edward Urban, Gregory 
Grogan, Lance Bohn and William Emerick.  Plaintiffs will continue to pursue their claims 
against the County. 
Pursuant to Rule 23(e) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, a plaintiff may not 
voluntarily dismiss or compromise any claim or party involved in a certified class without the 
approval of court.  Rule 23(e) states: 
10 
 

Case 2:06-cv-00927-TFM   Document 116    Filed 06/26/09   Page 11 of 13
The claims, issues, or defenses of a certified class may be settled, 
voluntarily dismissed, or compromised only with the court’s 
approval.  The following procedures apply to a proposed 
settlement, voluntary dismissal, or compromise: 
(1) The court must direct notice in a reasonable manner to 
all class member who would be bound by the proposal. 
(2) If the proposal would bind class members , the court 
may approve it only after a hearing and on finding that it is 
fair, reasonable and adequate. 
(3) The parties seeking approval must file statement 
identifying any agreement made in connection with the 
proposal. 
(4) If the class action was previously certified under Rule 
23(b)(3), the court may refuse to approve a settlement 
unless it affords a new opportunity to request exclusion to 
individual class member who had an earlier opportunity to 
request exclusion but did not do so. 
(5) Any class member may object to the proposal if it 
requires court approval under this subdivision (e); the 
objection may be withdrawn only with the court’s approval. 
 
Fed.R.Civ.P. 23(e). 
 
Plaintiffs now seek to dismiss the individual Defendants, Ramon Rustin, Edward Urban, 
Gregory Grogan, Lance Bohn and William Emerick.  Plaintiffs are not seeking any additional 
damages from these individual Defendants besides those that the plaintiffs can recover from the 
County of Allegheny.  Thus, absent class members will not be unfairly prejudiced.  Further, 
Plaintiffs intend to file a motion for this Court to provide Court approved notice to the class 
identifying the certification of this class and the parties.  Thus, absent class members will be 
fully apprised of the action and parties.  Finally, Class Counsel believes that it is in the class’ 
best interest to bring this matter to trial immediately rather than await a likely interlocutory 
appeal to the Third Circuit, which would stay this litigation.  Delay of this matter by pursuing 
individual defendants will not ultimately benefit the class. Thus, Plaintiffs join in Defendants’ 
motion to dismiss the individual defendants Ramon Rustin, Edward Urban, Gregory Grogan, 
Lance Bohn and William Emerick.
